Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: Interactive effects of predation and ecosystem size on arthropod food webs in Hawaiian forests fragmented by lava flows
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will investigate the combined effects of top predators and ecosystem size on the coexistence of species in food webs. Using numerous forest fragments of varying size that have been naturally created by lava flows in Hawai'i, the researchers will test the hypothesis that, as top predators, non-native rats alter food webs consisting of native birds, insects and spiders, with greater effects in smaller forest fragments. The study will involve experimental removal of rats, experimental exclusion of birds, stable isotope analysis of arthropods, and remote sensing analysis of forest size, complexity and productivity, all across a 100-fold gradient of forest fragment size.

Many forests around the world have been fragmented by development and pastoral land use, and also invaded by rats and other non-native predators. This project will improve the scientific basis for making management decisions, especially with regard to how non-native species removal can be used to restore native forests and how the effect may depend on forest size. This project will also enable the researchers to train a number of undergraduate and graduate students and postdoctoral fellows through their participation in research. Students will be recruited through internship programs at Stanford University and the University of Hawai'i, Hilo, which has a successful record of training under-represented students in environmental sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Habitat fragmentation by land use and development is a serious threat to persistence of biodiversity worldwide; it is also a natural process in the volcanic shield-building phase of oceanic islands.  A more recent impact to oceanic island systems is the introduction of non-native species, the impacts of which may be particularly severe because introduced species fill roles that did not exist previously. This project investigated the interactions of species in food webs, and how the effects of introduced predators may be contingent on ecosystem size. Using numerous forest fragments created naturally by volcanic lava flows (known as Hawaiian ‘kipuka’) that ranged 100-fold in area, we tested the hypothesis that non-native rats alter food webs consisting of native birds, insects and spiders. We expected greater impacts of invasive rats in smaller forest fragments.

In this ‘kipuka project’, we experimentally removed black and Polynesian rats (Rattus rattus and R. exulans) with continuous snap-trapping for 4 years, June 2011-June 2015, in 16 of 34 monitored kipuka ranging in size from 0.1 to 12 hectares. We sampled canopy arthropods each year from 2009-2013, and collaborative partners mist-netted and color-banded birds, assessed breeding success and survival, movement, and foraging behavior of passerines from 2011-2013. In January to May of 2012 and 2013, during peak bird breeding season, we established 120 netted bird exclosures in tree to test the impacts of birds on arthropod communities in rat-removed and control (rat-present) kipuka. Monitoring of rats using tracking tunnels (see image) demonstrated that populations were suppressed successfully in rat-removal kipuka: they were not detected again in trees and only rarely on the ground, while populations were unaffected in control kipuka.  

From samples collected in the forest canopies, arthropod abundance, biomass and species richness increased with increasing kipuka area (log10 transformed). As there is more foliage in larger kipuka (larger and more trees), diversity and the availability of arthropod food for vertebrates increases at an accelerating rate with forest area/size. We observed little evidence of direct impacts of rats on canopy arthropod abundance, biomass or diversity. However, birds suppress all three arthropod metrics, and as predicted, the strength of bird effects were diminished in the presence or rats and in small relative to large kipuka. Birds foraged higher in the canopy in the presence of rats, but small to medium-sized kipuka lack refuge for birds with few taller trees. Overall, we interpret these results as evidence that rats interfere with birds, either by changing their behavior or via limited direct predation. Because we see no evidence of rat effects on arthropods in kipuka-level removal experiments, it is unlikely that the mechanism of these effects is via interspecific exploitative competition for limited resources.

This study is the first systematic experimental field test, to our knowledge, of the interactive effects of omnivorous introduced predators on a gradient of ecosystem size. This study is particularly welcome in our discipline because of the unprecedented landscape spatial scale and moderate temporal extent (4 years) of the endeavor, and the comprehensive scope of the study, from bird demography, to insect biodiversity and food web composition, to ecosystem processes. Results are useful to public and private landowners who must manage non-native species, sustain native biodiversity, and provision ecosystem services. Our genetic analyses of rat and bird diets show significant dietary overlap, but also show that rats consume non-native gamebirds managed for hunting in the region.
